entry.title: IMO 2000/2
entry.summary:
Schur with Substitution

Let \(a\), \(b\), \(c\) be positive real numbers such that \(abc=1\). Prove that \[\left(a - 1 + \frac{1}{b}\right)\left(b - 1 + \frac{1}{c}\right)\left(c - 1 + \frac{1}{a}\right) \leq 1.\]

Solution

Let \(x\), \(y\), \(z\) be positve real numbers such that \(a = \frac{x}{y}\), \(b = \frac{y}{z}\), \(c = \frac{z}{x}\). Substituting the values in, we get that

\[\left(\frac{x + z - y}{y}\right)\left(\frac{y + x - z}{z}\right)\left(\frac{z + y - x}{x}\right) \leq 1.\]

Now multiplying by \(xyz\) and expanding, we see that \[\begin{align*} &\quad (x+z-y)(y+x-z)(z+y-x) \leq xyz \\ \iff&\quad -(x^3 + y^3 + z^3) + \sum_{sym}x^2y - 2xyz \leq xyz \\ \iff&\quad x^3 + y^3 + z^3 -\sum_{sym}x^2y + 3xyz \geq 0, \end{align*}\] which turns out to be Schur's inequality for the \(r = 1\) case.

\(\blacksquare\)
